author: yahoo
title: How will technology consumers react to Steve Jobs biopics? - Investors.com
text:
T he late Steve Jobs and Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) will command attention from yet another sector of humanity over the next month, as Hollywood and moviegoers will turn their gaze toward two biographical films, each with its own depiction of the technology giant's mercurial co-founder and longtime CEO. 
But will the tech juggernaut take a hit should either or both of the portrayals of Jobs create an unflattering impression of the tech icon? 
Tim Bajarin, a veteran tech consultant who has worked with Apple and a number of other companies, says that the answer is an unequivocal no.   View Enlarged Image 

"People do not buy products because of a personality. I didn't buy Windows because of (former Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT ) CEO) Bill Gates," Bajarin said. "If that would have been the case, most of us wouldn't have bought it. Not that Bill is a bad guy, but he was a geek." 
Jobs is the subject — some would say target — of what critics say is a scathing documentary, "Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine," which hit theaters Friday. 
Jobs' famous temper and reportedly difficult managerial style are the focus of director Alex Gibney, who interviews a number of Apple insiders to talk about their former chief's volatile personality. Gibney has produced several hard-hitting documentaries in recent years, including "Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room" and "Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief." 
Next month, Gibney's effort is to be followed by the simply titled feature film "Steve Jobs," from Comcast's (NASDAQ: CMCSA ) Universal Pictures unit, based on the authorized biography of Jobs from former Time writer Walter Isaacson. 
"Steve Jobs" could, depending on your perspective, offer a more balanced view of Jobs, though there is talk that the film might be a bit more critical than the book. "Steve Jobs" is set for release on Oct. 9, four days after the fourth anniversary of his 2011 death. 
Is this a case where the one-time face of the company and the company itself are inextricably intertwined? Jobs did, after all, preside over a 100-fold leap in Apple stock as it went from a split-adjusted price of around 58 cents when he retook the helm in early 1997 to nearly 60 a share at the time of his death. 
As of April, Apple stock had more than doubled since Jobs died, to a high of 134.54, but shares have retreated with the recent market downturn. Apple stock fell 1% Friday, to 109.27. Current Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook took over when Jobs resigned just before he died.
